Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: A New Method for Sampling Sea-Salt Aerosols
Award.AbstractNarration:
Sea-salt aerosol form in marine environments from breaking waves, white capping, or bursting bubbles. They remain suspended in the air as tiny droplets and affect visibility. These droplets, known as Giant Cloud Condensation Nuclei (GCCN), are also hypothesized to play a role in cloud and precipitation development. Measurements of GCCN are limited and primarily come from an instrument that requires placement on an expensive research aircraft. This award will allow for the development of a low-cost, 3D-printed instrument that can make measurements of GCCN from kites and unmanned aircraft. The measurements will help to resolve questions about the role of GCCN in the development of clouds and precipitation, which will potentially make an impact on weather and climate modeling. Students will be involved in the design and testing of the system, providing them with hands-on research activities.

The research team plans to develop a new, low-cost instrument to measure GCCN. GCCN are extremely efficient nuclei for condensation and rapid growth. Their role in cloud development is still considered an unknown in the cloud physics community. One hypotheses is that GCCN broaden the droplet spectrum and can accelerate precipitation initiation in warm clouds. GCCN are traditionally measured by exposing a microscope slide to the free air stream outside of an aircraft. The research team will develop a miniaturized version of the Giant Nucleus Impactor known as the mini-GNI that can be flown on kites or UASs. Kite measurements are initially targeted due to their ability to perform Eularian sampling at a consistent point over time. Also, multiple instruments can be attached to kites with the option of measuring multiple altitudes. The mini-GNI will be 3D-printed and run using a Raspberry Pi computer. The specific work tasks include testing of the kite setup, the Raspberry Pi system, and the complementary state variable measurements. The entire mini-GNI package will be flown multiple times and the samples will be collected and analyzed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Sea-salt aerosols are salt particles that exist suspended in the atmosphere as tiny micron-sized droplets, forming and existing primarily in the marine environment from air-sea interactions. These droplets are particularly important because they are always present over the ocean, forming from white capping, bursting bubbles, or breaking waves, they affect visibility, and they are hypothesized to play a role in cloud and precipitation development. The primary goal of this project was to create a new, low-cost, and easy to use 3D-printed instrument that could sample the sea-salt aerosol size distribution in the marine boundary layer on a ground-based platform.
To do this, Arduino and 3D printing technology were used to create the miniature-Giant Nucleus Impactor (mini-GNI) instrument (Figure 1). Multiple prototypes were designed and tested, and ultimately a dozen instruments were made that can be attached serially to a kite line to sample the sea-salt aerosol size distribution on polycarbonate slides at multiple altitudes simultaneously (Figure 2). The number and the size of sea-salt is especially difficult to measure regularly with current technology so the mini-GNI provides a new way to do this that does not require aircraft.
Multiple graduate students and undergraduate students, including an undergraduate instrumentation class, female and other minority students, were entrained to work on this project. Two masters students were at least partially funded by this project, and an undergraduate student was funded for a summer of research. A trip to the Research Aviation Facility at NCAR in Boulder, CO allowed for hands-on training during this project, and close collaboration with NCAR was essential for completion of the analysis portion of the project. Results were presented by the PI and students at international conferences. Ultimately the mini-GNI instrument was designed, built, tested, and used for sampling along the windward shores of Oahu in the Hawaiian Islands. More than 100 samples were taken from altitudes from the surface to 600 m, and we found a number of interesting things. First, large (14 micron) sea-salt aerosols were found as high as 600 m, showing that sea-salt from the ocean surface is able to make it up to cloud base. Second, we found that the traditional idea that sea-salt is primarily dependent on wind speed, was not the best analog for coastal sea-salt number or size. Instead, wave height, tied to coastal wave breaking, appeared to play a stronger role in the number and size of sea-salt in the coastal atmosphere (Figure 3). Finally, we were able to show that sea-salt can be sampled in a simple way using low-cost technology.
This project has the potential to revolutionize the way that sea-salt are sampled in future. The 3D print design, Arduino software, and other materials necessary for creating a mini-GNI instrument are shared publically on a github site so anyone can create their own instrument to sample sea-salt aerosol in their local environment. Increasing the ability to sample sea-salt aerosol number and size from ground based platforms enhances the understanding of aerosols and particulate matter in our atmosphere, shown to be one of the largest unknowns in climate.
